teaching_points: Bronchiectasis causes chronic airway inflammation and secretion production
Assess baseline oxygen requirement and exercise tolerance
Optimize preoperative bronchial hygiene with chest physiotherapy
Risk of postoperative respiratory failure with limited pulmonary reserve
Consider preoperative antibiotics for active infection
Thick secretions may obstruct endotracheal tube or bronchial blocker
Avoid dehydration which worsens secretion viscosity
Aggressive suctioning and bronchoscopy may be needed
Early extubation preferred to avoid ventilator-associated complications
Postoperative incentive spirometry and chest physiotherapy essential
Bronchiectasis results from irreversible airway dilation
Chronic cough and sputum production are hallmarks
Recurrent infections damage bronchial walls over time

anesthetic_considerations: Regional analgesia (thoracic epidural) for pain control and pulmonary toilet

teaching_points: Congenital heart defects classified as cyanotic (right-to-left shunt) or acyanotic (left-to-right shunt)
Failure to thrive indicates significant cardiac compromise affecting growth
Shunt direction determines oxygen saturation and clinical presentation
Eisenmenger syndrome can develop from chronic left-to-right shunting
Pulmonary vascular resistance changes affect shunt dynamics
Pediatric NPO: clear liquids 2 hours, breast milk 4 hours, formula 6 hours, solids 8 hours
Small children decompensate rapidly with NPO-induced hypovolemia
Inhalation induction with sevoflurane preferred in young children
Parent presence at induction reduces separation anxiety
Careful IV access in small veins, consider ultrasound guidance
Higher oxygen consumption (6-8 mL/kg/min) vs adults (3-4 mL/kg/min)
Larger body surface area to weight ratio increases heat loss
Immature hepatic enzyme systems affect drug metabolism
Infants have higher percentage of total body water

monitoring_needs: Pulse oximetry (pre and post-ductal if needed)
anesthetic_considerations: Minimize NPO time, consider dextrose-containing IV fluids
Avoid air bubbles in IV lines (risk of paradoxical embolism)
Maintain preload and avoid sudden SVR changes
Warm operating room, forced air warmer, warm IV fluids

teaching_points: Former preterm infants (<37 weeks gestation) at risk for postoperative apnea
Risk highest in infants <60 weeks postconceptual age
Bronchopulmonary dysplasia common in extreme prematurity (<28 weeks)
Reactive airways increase bronchospasm risk with airway manipulation
Consider regional anesthesia to avoid general anesthesia and intubation
Caudal block excellent for inguinal hernia repair in infants
Reduces general anesthetic requirement and postoperative apnea risk
Sevoflurane inhalation induction, then caudal placement
LMA or ETT acceptable for airway management during brief procedure
Postoperative apnea monitoring for minimum 12 hours if <60 weeks PCA
Premature lungs have decreased alveolar development and surfactant
Oxygen toxicity and mechanical ventilation contribute to BPD
Reactive airways result from chronic inflammation
Avoid high FiO2 unless necessary (target SpO2 92-95% in former preemies)

anesthetic_considerations: Light general anesthetic with LMA if caudal successful
Admit for overnight apnea monitoring if <60 weeks postconceptual age

teaching_points: Sickle cell disease: abnormal hemoglobin S polymerizes when deoxygenated
Vaso-occlusive crisis triggered by hypoxia, dehydration, acidosis, hypothermia
Target hemoglobin >10 g/dL for moderate-risk surgery
Preoperative transfusion may be needed to reduce HbS percentage
Maintain oxygen saturation >95%, avoid tourniquet if possible
Tonsillectomy is shared airway procedure requiring coordination with surgeon
RAE (Ring-Adair-Elwyn) oral ETT prevents kinking during mouth gag
Smooth emergence critical to prevent bleeding from agitation
Dexamethasone and ondansetron for PONV prophylaxis
Careful suctioning under direct visualization before extubation
Sickling occurs when HbS concentration high and oxygen tension low
Sickled cells cause microvascular occlusion and hemolysis
Chronic anemia with baseline hemoglobin 6-9 g/dL compensated by increased cardiac output
Acute chest syndrome can occur postoperatively

anesthetic_considerations: Maintain normothermia with forced air warmer and warm fluids
Avoid hypothermia, hypoxia, dehydration, acidosis, stasis
Consider preoperative transfusion if Hgb <10 g/dL
Pain management to prevent crisis (multimodal approach)
Smooth emergence to prevent agitation and bleeding

teaching_points: Autism spectrum disorder affects communication, social interaction, and behavior
Non-verbal patients cannot report pain or discomfort
Sensory overstimulation triggers agitation and meltdowns
Preoperative tour and picture books reduce anxiety
Continue antiepileptic medications perioperatively to prevent seizures
Non-verbal patient requires alternative induction approach
IV induction may be impossible due to lack of cooperation
Inhalation induction with sevoflurane often necessary despite age
Midazolam premedication may paradoxically increase agitation
Avoid seizure-inducing drugs (enflurane, high-dose opioids)
Have antiepileptic medications available
Many antiepileptic drugs induce hepatic enzymes (phenytoin, carbamazepine)
Increased drug clearance may require higher anesthetic doses
Check antiepileptic drug levels preoperatively
Valproic acid can cause thrombocytopenia and bleeding

anesthetic_considerations: Parent present throughout induction if helpful
Continue antiepileptic medications (oral or IV equivalent)
Smooth emergence in quiet recovery area
Pain assessment challenging - use behavioral scales

teaching_points: Type 1 diabetes: absolute insulin deficiency requires continuous insulin
Brittle diabetes = wide glucose fluctuations, difficult to control
Target perioperative glucose 100-180 mg/dL in children
Never stop basal insulin completely (risk of DKA)
Celiac disease may affect absorption and nutritional status
Emergency appendectomy requires rapid glucose assessment and control
Continue insulin pump or IV insulin infusion
Check glucose every 1-2 hours intraoperatively
Dextrose-containing IV fluids (D5LR or D5NS) with insulin
Avoid prolonged NPO status preoperatively
Surgical stress increases glucose via cortisol and epinephrine release
Insulin promotes glucose uptake and prevents lipolysis/ketogenesis
Basal insulin required even when NPO to prevent DKA
Short-acting insulin for correction of hyperglycemia

monitoring_needs: Continuous glucose monitoring or frequent checks
anesthetic_considerations: Minimize NPO time or start IV early with dextrose
Insulin infusion protocol (0.05-0.1 units/kg/hr with dextrose)
Glucose checks: baseline, hourly, and postop
Stress-dose steroids NOT needed for primary adrenal insufficiency

teaching_points: Cerebral palsy: non-progressive brain injury causing motor dysfunction
Gastrostomy tube indicates severe dysphagia and aspiration risk
Chronic aspiration causes recurrent pneumonia and reactive airways
Cannot communicate pain - relies on behavioral cues and vital signs
Gastroesophageal reflux disease common in CP patients
Rapid sequence induction indicated for aspiration risk
Empty G-tube and consider metoclopramide/H2-blocker preoperatively
Muscle contractures make positioning extremely difficult
Pressure ulcer risk very high - meticulous padding essential
Cannot report postoperative pain - use pain assessment scales (FLACC)
Avoid succinylcholine if patient has muscle atrophy or contractures
May have abnormal response to muscle relaxants
Chronic lung disease reduces pulmonary reserve
Temperature regulation impaired in some CP patients

anesthetic_considerations: Full stomach precautions - RSI with cricoid pressure
Extreme care with positioning - photograph patient position preop
Postoperative respiratory support may be needed

teaching_points: Asthma most common chronic pediatric disease affecting 8-10% of children
Food allergies may predict latex allergy or anaphylaxis risk
Document specific allergens and reactions preoperatively
Reactive airway increases bronchospasm risk with airway manipulation
Separation anxiety common in age 7 children
Myringotomy is brief procedure (10-15 minutes) ideal for LMA
Inhalation induction with sevoflurane in child with IV fear
N2O contraindicated (expands middle ear gas, displaces tubes)
Emergence delirium common in young children after sevoflurane
Parent presence at induction reduces separation anxiety
Anaphylaxis: IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation
Cross-reactivity between food allergies and latex (banana, avocado, kiwi)
Have epinephrine immediately available for allergic reactions
Bronchospasm and laryngeal edema are life-threatening manifestations

anesthetic_considerations: Parent present for induction if beneficial
Albuterol pretreatment if recent asthma symptoms
LMA preferred over ETT (less airway stimulation)

teaching_points: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis affects joints and may involve cervical spine
Chronic steroid use (>3 weeks of >5mg prednisone daily) suppresses HPA axis
Atlanto-axial instability risk with cervical involvement
Immunosuppressed from disease and medications (infection risk)
Adrenal crisis can occur if stress-dose steroids not given
Cervical spine films if neck involvement (atlanto-axial instability)
Manual in-line stabilization during intubation if C-spine disease
Stress-dose steroids: hydrocortisone 100mg IV at induction
Fragile skin from steroids - gentle tape application
Limited joint mobility affects positioning
Chronic steroids suppress adrenal cortisol production
Surgical stress normally increases cortisol 2-10 fold
Adrenal insufficiency causes hypotension refractory to vasopressors
Stress-dose steroids provide 'physiologic' cortisol during stress

monitoring_needs: Careful blood pressure monitoring for adrenal insufficiency
anesthetic_considerations: Cervical spine precautions if neck involved
Fragile skin - minimize tape, gentle positioning

teaching_points: Cystic fibrosis: genetic disorder causing thick secretions in lungs and pancreas
Chronic pulmonary infections (Pseudomonas, Staph aureus) damage airways
Malnutrition from pancreatic insufficiency despite enzyme replacement
Baseline oxygen saturation and pulmonary function tests guide management
PICC line for IV antibiotics during pulmonary exacerbations
Optimize pulmonary status preoperatively (antibiotics, chest PT)
Thick secretions obstruct airways - aggressive suctioning needed
Maintain hydration to prevent secretion inspissation
Avoid high FiO2 unless necessary (absorptive atelectasis)
Postoperative chest physiotherapy essential
CFTR gene mutation causes defective chloride channel
Thick mucus in lungs leads to obstruction and infection
Pancreatic enzyme deficiency causes malabsorption
Median survival now >40 years with modern therapy

anesthetic_considerations: Continue chest physiotherapy and bronchodilators preoperatively
Avoid prolonged NPO - early IV fluids
MAC or sedation may be sufficient for PICC placement
If general anesthesia needed: LMA acceptable for brief procedure
Pain control to allow deep breathing and coughing

teaching_points: Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) associated with multiple comorbidities
50% have congenital heart defects (ASD, VSD, AVSD, tetralogy of Fallot)
Atlanto-axial instability in 10-20% due to ligamentous laxity
Macroglossia and midface hypoplasia cause difficult airway
Obstructive sleep apnea common from adenotonsillar hypertrophy
Cervical spine films to rule out atlanto-axial instability before surgery
Manual in-line stabilization during intubation if C-spine instability
Large tongue and small mouth make laryngoscopy difficult
Cardiac lesion determines anesthetic management (avoid SVR changes)
Postoperative airway obstruction risk from tongue edema
ASD/VSD create left-to-right shunt (increased pulmonary blood flow)
Avoid increases in PVR (hypoxia, hypercarbia, acidosis)
Air bubbles in IV can cause paradoxical embolism
Endocarditis prophylaxis if unrepaired or recently repaired defect

anesthetic_considerations: Cervical spine X-rays before surgery if not done
Video laryngoscope or fiberoptic bronchoscope available
Avoid air bubbles in all IV lines
Antibiotic prophylaxis for endocarditis if indicated
Maintain cardiac output and avoid sudden SVR changes
Careful extubation - high risk of obstruction from large tongue

teaching_points: AAA defined as aortic diameter >3 cm (normal 2 cm)
Rupture risk increases exponentially when >5.5 cm
Cross-clamping aorta causes sudden increase in afterload and myocardial oxygen demand
Unclamping causes hypotension from reperfusion and washout of metabolites
Renal ischemia during cross-clamp time
AAA repair is highest risk vascular surgery (30-day mortality 3-5%)
High RCRI score: age >70, vascular surgery, hypertension
Coronary artery disease screening essential preoperatively
Arterial line and central venous pressure monitoring mandatory
Large bore IV access for potential massive hemorrhage
Goal-directed hemodynamic management reduces complications
Gradual cross-clamp application allows compensation
Communicate with surgeon before unclamping (volume load, vasopressors ready)
Cell saver for blood conservation
Epidural analgesia improves outcomes but coagulation must be normal

monitoring_needs: Foley catheter with hourly urine output
anesthetic_considerations: Large bore IV access (2x 16-18g) and rapid infuser
Communication with surgeon for cross-clamp and unclamp
Volume and vasopressor ready for unclamp hypotension

teaching_points: PAD results from atherosclerosis affecting lower extremity arteries
Diabetes accelerates atherosclerosis and increases amputation risk
Gangrene indicates critical limb ischemia requiring urgent revascularization
PAD is marker of systemic atherosclerosis (coronary, carotid, renal)
High cardiac risk - need careful preoperative assessment
Regional anesthesia (spinal/epidural) may reduce cardiac complications
Peripheral nerve blocks (femoral, sciatic) provide excellent analgesia
Long surgery duration (3-5 hours) may exceed neuraxial duration
Combined epidural-general technique optimal
Maintain perfusion pressure to ischemic limb
Diabetes causes microvascular and macrovascular complications
Autonomic neuropathy increases perioperative cardiac risk
Poor circulation delays wound healing postoperatively
Infection risk higher in diabetics with ischemic tissue

monitoring_needs: Consider central line for long case
anesthetic_considerations: Multimodal pain control (epidural, peripheral nerve block)

teaching_points: Carotid stenosis >70% significantly increases stroke risk
Previous stroke indicates vulnerable brain with poor collateral flow
Carotid surgery prevents future stroke but has perioperative stroke risk 2-3%
Need to balance cerebral perfusion during carotid cross-clamping
Hemodynamic instability common from carotid sinus manipulation
Regional anesthesia (cervical plexus block) allows neurologic monitoring
General anesthesia requires EEG or cerebral oximetry monitoring
Maintain MAP 20% above baseline to ensure cerebral perfusion
Shunt placement if EEG changes during cross-clamp
Baroreceptor dysfunction causes postop BP lability
Cerebral autoregulation maintains constant CBF between MAP 50-150 mmHg
Chronic hypertension shifts autoregulation curve rightward
Carotid stenosis reduces flow reserve - brain relies on contralateral flow
Hypotension during cross-clamp can cause stroke

anesthetic_considerations: Regional (cervical plexus block) vs general anesthesia decision
Maintain MAP 20% above baseline (typically MAP 80-100 mmHg)
Phenylephrine or norepinephrine for MAP support
Smooth emergence to prevent hypertension (neck hematoma risk)

teaching_points: Varicose veins result from venous valve incompetence
Chronic venous insufficiency causes skin changes and ulcers
Generally low-risk outpatient procedure
Geriatric patients require careful assessment despite ASA II status
Relief-seeking patient usually cooperative and motivated

topics: Spinal vs general for vein surgery
teaching_points: Spinal anesthesia excellent choice for lower extremity vein surgery
Avoid prolonged spinal in elderly (urinary retention, hypotension)
General anesthesia with LMA alternative for brief cases
Tumescent anesthesia (local) reduces systemic anesthetic needs
Early mobilization reduces DVT risk postoperatively
Tumescent technique uses dilute local anesthetic (lidocaine) in large volumes
Slow absorption reduces peak levels and toxicity
Vasoconstriction from epinephrine reduces bleeding

anesthetic_considerations: Compression stockings on opposite leg for DVT prophylaxis

teaching_points: ESRD requires renal replacement therapy (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis)
Hyperkalemia is life-threatening complication in ESRD
Fluid overload common - assess volume status preoperatively
AV fistula preferred over catheter for long-term dialysis access
Time dialysis appropriately (ideally within 24 hours before surgery)
Regional anesthesia (brachial plexus block) ideal for AV fistula creation
Preserves arm veins for future access
Avoid renally-cleared drugs (morphine, pancuronium)
Minimize nephrotoxic drugs (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides)
Careful fluid management (may be anuric)
Avoid morphine (metabolite accumulation causes prolonged sedation)
Use cisatracurium (Hoffman elimination, not renal)
Remifentanil ideal opioid (ester hydrolysis)
Many drugs require dose reduction in ESRD

monitoring_needs: ECG for hyperkalemia (tall T waves, wide QRS)
Avoid blood pressure cuff on fistula arm
anesthetic_considerations: Dialysis within 24 hours of surgery to optimize status
Regional anesthesia (supraclavicular or axillary block) preferred
Avoid blood pressure cuff and IV on fistula arm
Listen to fistula thrill postoperatively to confirm patency

surgical_type: First rib resection for thoracic outlet syndrome

teaching_points: TOS caused by compression of neurovascular bundle at thoracic outlet
Chronic pain indicates longstanding nerve compression
First rib resection decompresses brachial plexus and subclavian vessels
Brachial plexus injury risk during surgery
Frustrated patients often have tried multiple conservative therapies
Lateral or supine position with arm abducted
Careful positioning to avoid worsening nerve compression
Interscalene or paravertebral block for postoperative pain
Pneumothorax risk from surgical approach near pleura
Chest X-ray postoperatively to rule out pneumothorax
Chronic pain causes central sensitization
Multimodal analgesia (regional, NSAIDs, gabapentinoids) reduces opioid needs
Nerve compression causes neuropathic pain components

anesthetic_considerations: Interscalene or paravertebral block for analgesia
Pain management expectations - may take time for nerve recovery

teaching_points: Popliteal aneurysm: arterial dilation behind knee (>2x normal diameter)
High risk of thrombosis or embolization causing acute limb ischemia
Smoking major risk factor for all aneurysms
May be bilateral - check contralateral leg
Limb loss risk if thromboses before surgery
Spinal or epidural anesthesia effective for popliteal surgery
Combined sciatic-femoral nerve block alternative
Maintain adequate perfusion pressure to limb
Heparinization during surgery - check coagulation before neuraxial
Distal pulse checks postoperatively essential
Smoking cessation >8 weeks preop improves wound healing
Recent cessation still beneficial for pulmonary function
Nicotine causes vasoconstriction affecting graft perfusion

anesthetic_considerations: Regional anesthesia (spinal/epidural or peripheral nerve blocks)
Check coagulation before neuraxial (will receive heparin)
Maintain perfusion pressure to affected limb
Keep limb warm to promote perfusion

teaching_points: DVT high risk for pulmonary embolism (potentially fatal)
IVC filter prevents PE when anticoagulation contraindicated
Recurrent DVT despite anticoagulation is indication for filter
Obesity is major risk factor for VTE
Procedure usually done under moderate sedation
IVC filter placement typically performed with moderate sedation
Obesity increases risk of airway obstruction during sedation
Supine position may worsen breathing in obese patients
Have airway equipment immediately available
Brief procedure (30-60 minutes) in interventional radiology
Virchow's triad: stasis, hypercoagulability, endothelial injury
Obesity causes stasis and chronic inflammation (hypercoagulable)
DVT most commonly originates in deep veins of legs

anesthetic_considerations: Moderate sedation with propofol infusion or intermittent doses
Brief procedure - recovery and discharge same day

teaching_points: Type B aortic dissection involves descending thoracic aorta
Dissection creates false lumen that can rupture (fatal)
Severe pain is hallmark symptom
Blood pressure control critical to prevent propagation and rupture
Emergency indicates complications (rupture, malperfusion, refractory pain)
Target MAP 60-80 mmHg and heart rate <60 bpm (reduce shear stress)
Beta-blockade FIRST, then vasodilators (avoid reflex tachycardia)
Large bore IV access and arterial line pre-induction
Type and cross 6+ units blood
TEVAR less invasive than open repair but still high risk
Intimal tear allows blood to separate aortic layers
Shear stress (dP/dt) propagates dissection more than absolute pressure
Beta-blockade reduces contractility and shear stress
Hypertension and hypotension both dangerous
Spinal cord ischemia risk from covering spinal arteries

anesthetic_considerations: Arterial line pre-induction (awake or rapid sequence)
Maintain MAP 60-80 mmHg (avoid hypertension and hypotension)
Large bore IV access x2 and rapid infuser
Spinal drain consideration for cord protection
ICU postoperatively with arterial monitoring continued
